awd_titl_txt: 3D Motion and Swarm Control of Magnetically Propelled Microrobots for in vivo Particulate Drug Delivery
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will demonstrate the use of rotating magnetic fields to propel and steer magnetic microswimmers for medical applications such as drug delivery. Unlike previous work in this area, this project considers swarms of microswimmers instead of single vehicles, and allows fluids with non-ideal behavior characteristic of, for example, mucus. The results will be experimentally validated using a controllable synthetic biofluid. The results will guide future development of control systems for microrobotics, and advance towards practically controllable magnetic microswimmers in vivo. A complimentary outreach program will provide and cultivate a unique, interdisciplinary training environment for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students, exploiting eye-catching microswimmer control, drug delivery, and haptic devices.

The PI has recently demonstrated that achiral magnetic rigid geometries are capable of propulsion when rotated by a magnetic field. This project builds upon that demonstration, by formulating the motion control problem in the setting of stochastic differential equations, in order to create a stochastic control system for 3D motion and swarm control of magnetic microswimmers. Motion control of microswimmers is accomplished with magnetic control and computer vision feedback. Notably, variations in the physical parameters of the individual microswimmers will be leveraged to address uncertainty in the fluid environment. The approach will be used to formulate control and coordination schemes for the motion of a large number of microswimmers in heterogeneous 2D and 3D workspaces, using motion planning and control frameworks that address issues such as controllability and optimality. The results will be experimentally validated in a non-Newtonian fluid with controllable parameters that simulates a biological environment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content

To sum up, the key outcomes of NSF program have been

(1)   Characterization of the kinematics of particle-based swimmers in three dimensions under low Reynolds number environmental disturbances.

(2)   Analyzing viscoelastic stresses caused from the environments and their effects on the microswimmers.

(3)   To develop 3D vision-based tracking and feedback control.

(4)   To develop a strategy for swarm control of particle-based swimmers.

The first outcome is achieved with single magnetic particle, heterogeneously flagellated microswimmer and dubbed flagellated Janus particle (FJPs). Flagellated microswimmer and FJPs are synthetized by our research group.  We observed spherical magnetic microparticles to translate while exposed to uniform rotating magnetic fields in both a 4% mucin solution and a 0.25% polyacrylamide solution. Also, propulsion velocity of flagellated and non-flagellated microparticles were examined under different mediums.

For the second outcome, a propulsion mechanism is proposed and verified for spherical microparticles, the simplest microswimmers to date, arising from nonlinear viscoelastic effects in rotating flows similar to the rod-climbing effect. We analyzed the viscoelastic stresses caused from the environments and their effects on the microswimmers in 4 different fluid media which are 0.2% Methylcellulose, 15% NaCl, 0.25% Polyacyrylamide, and 4% Mucin.

To develop 3D vision-based tracking and feedback control of microswimmers, a magnetic tweezer system is built. Experiments proceeded showed the flexible manipulation and powerful strength generation of magnetic tweezer system controlling microrobots in 3D space. Besides, haptic device integration with magnetic tweezer system is achieved by building up the data communication channel between those two systems to transmit real time experiment video and control input back and forth at user end (haptic device)

For achieving the swarm control of particle-based swimmers, a closed-loop control algorithm based on image processing and hardware integration through MATLAB was developed to automatically operate external power supplies connected to the magnetic tweezer system. Experimental analysis shows the closed-loop navigation of a microparticle swarm moving freely in both 2D and 3D environments. Results show highly consistent trajectories within the swarm of microrobots.

This project will have a significant effect on the development of microrobotics for use in in vivo environments. Investigating how microswimmers are affected by environmental factors and disturbances will allow for correct adaptation to multiple environments found within the human body. Also, by designing and deploying powerful magnetic tweezer system, more applications and tasks can be achieved with microswimmers. Successfully characterizing these will result in in medical techniques such as targeted drug delivery, minimally invasive surgery, cell manipulation, and in vivo microscale assembly. These results will also have broad effect on fluid dynamics, as the fundamental mechanism for propulsion of single particles in non-Newtonian fluids, using purely rotating fields, has not been documented or reported until now.

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2021
Modified by: Minjun Kim

Image
  • 3bead microswimmer is navigating through Newtonian fluidic environment under rotating magnetic field
    MinJun Kim
    Public Domain
    Minjun Kim
    Archiral Robotic Microswimmer
